fr:title.text: Presheaf category over a small category is totally distributive

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf category over a small category is totally distributive

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A presheaf category over a small categroy \mathcal {C} is not only a total category, as proven in Example , but also a totally distributive category. This is because \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* has a left adjoint \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}_! a.k.a. the left Kan extension. We need to be careful because \mathsf {Psh}^2 (\mathcal {C}) is not locally small. The colimit formula for (pointwise) left Kan extensions is \operatorname {Lan}_{\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}} F(G) = \operatorname *{colim}_{p : \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X) \leftarrow G} F(X) where F, G \in \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) and X ranges over \mathcal {C}. (The reversal of arrow comes from the contravariance of presheaves.) This is still a small limit, so it is fine.

For the special case of \mathcal {C} = 1, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* : \mathsf {Psh}(\mathsf {Set}) \to \mathsf {Set} evaluates at 1. We get \operatorname {Lan}_{1} F(G) = \operatorname *{colim}_{1 \leftarrow G} F = F where F, G are sets. So the left adjoint is the constant functor functor \Delta , such that \Delta (X)(Y) = X.

Given a locally small category \mathcal {C}, the yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) has four consecutive left adjoints iff \mathcal {C} is equivalent to \mathsf {Set}. See Example and Example for examples with one and two left adjoints, and Theorem for the four consecutive left adjoint over \mathsf {Set}.

The first three functors appear in Example and Example . The next adjoint \operatorname {ev}_0\dashv \Delta is dual to \Delta \dashv \operatorname {ev}_1, and it is also not hard to see manually. Finally, a natural transform 0_! (X) \to F consists of a single map X \to F(0), since all the other components are empty functions, hence trivial. Moreover, 0_! does not preserve products, so no more left adjoints are possible.

fr:title.text: Presheaf category over a small category is total

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf category over a small category is total

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a small category \mathcal {C}, the locally small category \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) is a total category. In fact, the left adjoint to \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) \to \mathsf {Psh}^2(\mathcal {C}) is given by \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^*, i.e. the map that sends the double presheaf R to the presheaf X \mapsto R(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).

To see this, we compute \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C})}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* R, F) to be the set of natural transforms that assign an arrow R(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)) \to F(X) for every object X. On the other hand, \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}^2(\mathcal {C})}(R, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} F) assigns an arrow R(G) \to \hom (G, F) for every presheaf G. The latter obviously have a map to the former, and we need to prove that any map in the former uniquely extends to the latter. G is a colimit of representables, so we can decompose \hom (G, F) into a limit of F(X). The naturality requirement then forces a unique value for each component.

In particular, if \mathcal {C} = 0, we get a left adjoint for the yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Psh}(0) = 1 \to \mathsf {Psh}(1) = \mathsf {Set}. In this case \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} is essentially picking out the terminal object, and \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* is the unique functor. We can also take \mathcal {C} = 1, then \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathsf {Set}), and the left adjoint is F \mapsto F(1), evaluating the presheaf at the singleton set. It is also possible to calculate this directly via the colimit characterization of total cocompleteness.

Given a locally small category \mathcal {C}, if the Yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) has a left adjoint \operatorname {?}, then we say teh category is total, or totally cocomplete. This is equivalent to requiring the colimit of \pi _F : \int F \to \mathcal {C} to exist for every presheaf F, which is the value of L(F). Notice that \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} being fully faithful implies the counit \operatorname {?}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)) \to A is an isomorphism.

The universal property of the colimit says \hom (\operatorname *{colim} \pi _F, X) \cong \lim _{(Y, p)} \hom (Y, X). Using the characterization of limits in \mathsf {Set}, an element in this set maps F(Y) to \hom (Y, X) for each Y naturally, which is exactly \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).

Given a total category, if the left adjoint \operatorname {?} has a further left adjoint, then it preserves all limits. Since \operatorname {?} is a kind of colimit operator, this condition is a strong version of complete distributivity. Therefore we call the category totally distributive.
